webTitle: Primark seeks eurozone expansion

fields.standfirst: George Weston, chief executive of parent company, says he is not deterred by fears of a long recession
fields.body:
Primark is pressing ahead with expansion in the crisis hit eurozone as the cheap chic formula that has won over British shoppers is also proving to be a hit there.

George Weston, chief executive of parent Associated British Foods, said it was not deterred by fears of a long recession in the eurozone as new stores in Spain, Germany, Portugal and the Netherlands had exceeded the company's expectations, helping the chain post a 15% increase in sales to £1.6bn in the 24 weeks to 4 March. "We're not in Greece," joked Weston, adding: "The Netherlands only went bad yesterday, so that is new news."

A fresh wave of store openings, including four more in Spain, are planned for the second half. "Despite the difficult economic circumstances we continue to open stores [in Spain] profitably," said Weston. "People are trading across to Primark either to save money or because they have never seen anything like it before." Signalling the extent of its ambitions for continental Europe the retailer has built a new 37,000 sq metre (400,000 sq ft) depot in Germany.

Primark, which has 156 out of a total of 233 stores in the UK, was one of the few retailers to prosper during the recession as hard up Britons cut their coats to fit their cloth. Like-for-likes sales were up 2% for the chain as a whole with the figure for its British stores "better than 1%" as coloured skinny jeans for £11 and "shrunken" blazers for £19 pulled in the cost-conscious fashion crowd.

"A strong Christmas trading period combined with relatively robust sales since the New Year has put Primark as one of the high flyers on the downbeat UK and European retail scene," said Conlumino analyst Simon Chinn. "Even though there are clear signs that eurozone consumers are reining in their spending, Primark's low price points and fashion forward ranges appeal to the price sensitivity of consumers amid the current austerity drive."

Profits at Primark, which generates a third of the grocery-to-retail conglomerate's profits, were up 2% at £154m as the chain absorbed higher cotton costs rather than pass them on to customers. Cotton prices have since fallen back and that is expected to be reflected in a "substantial" increase in profitability for the full year.

"We expect Primark to return to strong profits growth from the second half, driven by the excellent top-line momentum in the business," said Panmure Gordon analyst Graham Jones. "Primark's new stores are trading strongly and we believe there is a good pipeline for space expansion beyond 2012." The shares closed up nearly 2%, or 24p at £12.39.

webTitle: Shell makes £1.1bn Cove Energy bid

fields.standfirst: Oil company looks to take prime position in east African gas reserve market in face of competition from Asian firms
fields.body:
Shell has edged ahead of Asian competition in the scramble for east Africa's gas reserves by making a recommended £1.1bn bid for Cove Energy.

The Anglo-Dutch group received the backing of Cove's directors after matching a bid from PTT Exploration, the Thai-state controlled oil firm. Shell and PTT have been drawn to the company's 8.5% stake in a natural gas block off the coast of Mozambique that may contain 30tn cubic feet of reserves – which can then be shipped across the Indian Ocean to the gas-hungry Asian market.

Shell acknowledged that other bidders could still announce "competing offers for Cove", with Gail India and Oil & Natural Gas Corporation – both from the sub-continent – thought to be possible joint bidders. PTT said it was "considering its options" as analysts speculated that the company could return with a higher bid.

One analyst, however, said the Mozambique government was likely to back Shell as the bidder that offered the most expertise in extracting gas from the Rovuma Offshore Area 1 gas-block. The deal is conditional on government approval. Andrew Matharu, analyst at Westhouse Securities, said: "A key component of this is how the Mozambique authorities want to develop their resources and a project of this scale needs an oil major with the financial resources and the expertise of bringing world class scale projects to fruition so you need someone like Shell."

Michael Blaha, Cove's executive chairman, said he expected state backing. "I am confident, following our discussions with the government of Mozambique, that timely consent for Shell's offer will be forthcoming." Cove's directors own 4.38% of the business, with the transaction valuing their stake at £42.5m. Analysts at Investec noted an increased in Cove's share price in the wake of the Shell announcement and said PTT could return with a higher bid. "Competing offers can still be made and the shares will now likely trade to a slight premium on the hope that PTT will trump Shell," said Investec analysts in a note to investors. Shell's 220p a share offer represents a 13% increase on an initial offer of 195p a share, lodged in February.

Shell is seeking to reduce its dependence on oil in favour of gas and east Africa has emerged as a target area for energy majors with similar ambitions. Anadarko Petroleum, a US firm, owns a third of the Rovuma field, followed by Mitsui of Japan with 20%, with two Indian oil groups owning 10% each. Mozambique's state oil company owns a 15% stake in Rovuma. Elsewhere, Italy's Eni, Norway's Statoil and the UK's BG Group have also discovered gas off Mozambique and Tanzania, although Shell has not been successful so far.

Shell will increase spending on oil and gas exploration this year by 35% to $5bn and has a strong presence in the gas market as the world's largest manager of ships for transporting liquefied natural gas (LNG) and supplied 30% of global LNG volumes last year. East Africa is tipped to become a major gas producing region in the wake of the Rovuma discovery, with China and India among the field's likely Asian customers.

Shell and Cove did not comment on the capital gains tax issue that is clouding the sale process. Cove said last month that it will be subject to a tax rate of 12.8% on the capital gains from selling its Mozambique assets. Cove also owns assets in Kenya.

webTitle: Parliament urged to force companies into tax admissions

fields.standfirst: IDC seeks transparency from oil, gas and mining firms over amount of tax paid in developing countries
fields.body:
A parliamentary inquiry is likely to press the government into signing an international agreement to force oil, gas and mining companies to report how much tax they pay to developing countries.

The recommendation is expected to follow the conclusion of a series of select committee hearings in front of the International Development Committee, including Tuesday's session where two of the largest multinationals listed on the London Stock Exchange insisted it would be difficult and costly for them to make wider disclosures on taxation.

Senior executives from commodity trading group Glencore and brewer SAB Miller appeared to resist calls by campaign groups and development agencies for more transparency. The committee's chairman, Malcolm Bruce, said that one proposal being considered was for the UK to commit to signing up to Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, a programme designed to increase transparency over payments by companies to governments and to government-linked entities. Bruce said: "The US is considering signing up [to EITI]. Colombia is committed. The UK doesn't appear to be. That may well be ... a clear omission."

During questioning Tim Scott, global head of tax at Glencore, said: "For country by country reporting of financial information, there are pros and cons. The pros are the transparency. The cons are the cost of producing this information in a reliable and audited format. The second potential disadvantage is with this information it is not clear to me that anybody would be any the wiser on the level of taxation paid or whether the right tax had been paid at all. That is simply because one has to look at financial reports in the context of the tax law and tax returns before one gets a very clear idea. So I'm not too sure that this is amazingly useful."

Glencore has previously stated its commitment to the EITI and providing a breakdown of its tax payments by region.

Graham Mackay, chief executive of SAB Miller, said to the committee: "This transparency drive to achieve a right outcome, we believe is doomed."

The EITI was announced by then prime minister Tony Blair at the World Summit for Sustainable Development in Johannesburg in 2002. Despite it being originated in the UK, the British government has never signed up to the scheme. So far, most of the countries that have implemented EITI are developing countries, although last September President Obama committed the US. He said: "We're continuing our leadership of the global effort against corruption, by building on legislation that now requires oil, gas, and mining companies to disclose the payments that foreign governments demand of them. Today, I can announce that the United States will join the global initiative in which these industries, governments and civil society, all work together for greater transparency so that taxpayers receive every dollar they're due from the extraction of natural resources."

The select committee is expected to publish its report in the next six weeks.

webTitle: European stock markets recover poise after panic sell-off

fields.standfirst: Clashes in Dutch parliament over austerity measures fail to dent investor confidence in country's ability to fix finances
fields.body:
Europe's financial markets have recovered their poise after Monday's panic sell-off, despite clashes in the Dutch parliament over the country's austerity measures.

Share prices plunged at the start of the week, after Socialist François Hollande's strong showing in Sunday's first round of the French presidential election.

Nervous investors fear that support for Hollande, and the surprise collapse of the Dutch government, reveal a growing Europe-wide backlash against the austerity policies Brussels believes are the only way of safeguarding the single currency.

However, the Netherlands managed a successful debt auction on Tuesday, selling €2bn (£1.6bn) of bonds in two minutes, suggesting financial markets have not lost confidence in the country's ability to fix its finances.

Analyst Lyn Graham-Taylor of Rabobank said the results were "by no means a disaster given we've seen the biggest upheaval ahead of a Dutch bond sale for many years".

The smooth running of the debt sale helped to restore a mood of calm to financial markets and, in London the FTSE 100 closed up 43 points, or 0.78%, at 5709, while the French market bounced by more than 2%, and the German DAX by more than 1%.

The Dutch political crisis deepened, however, as opposition politicians said they could not back the prime minister's budget plans, raising doubts over whether the country can meet the 3%-of-GDP deficit target imposed by Brussels. Without new spending cuts the deficit is expected to be 4.6% of GDP.

Mark Rutte, who offered his resignation as prime minister on Monday, appealed for cross-party support to impose an austerity package worth between €14bn and €16bn, but Socialist leader Emile Roemer said: "I understand that you have to bring finances in order but you cannot cut rigorously because it hurts the economy and people. Three per cent is not feasible."

Geert Wilders, of the far-right Freedom Party, which had backed the government for 18 months before withdrawing its support over the weekend, said: "We don't want to cut spending by €14bn and at the same time transfer billions of euros to Brussels for the horrible ESM [European Stability Mechanism] emergency fund and the weak Greeks".

Rutte warned: "The problems are serious, the economy is stalling, employment is under pressure and government debt is growing faster than the Netherlands can afford. Those are the facts and nobody can run away from them. I'm standing here without pretences, it is up to parliament and the voters."

The Dutch had previously been among the most hardline governments in arguing that other countries should stick to strict spending limits and be punished for breaking fiscal rules.

Fresh evidence of the impact of the latest austerity measures on Greece's recession-ravaged government came from Bank of Greece governor Giorgos Provopoulos, who predicted that the economy would shrink by 5% this year, with wages set to decline by another 10%.

The hefty price of the deficit-cutting measures Greece signed up to as part of its latest bailout deal is helping to boost support for fringe political parties in the runup to elections next month, which could make it hard to form a stable government. Unemployment in Greece is already above 20%.

With Hollande pledging that he will seek to renegotiate the tough "fiscal compact" which allows Brussels to impose strict spending limits on eurozone member countries, there are growing fears in financial markets that the carefully negotiated Europe-wide deal that came with the rescue package for Greece could be about to collapse.

webTitle: FSA chief criticises City bonuses

fields.standfirst: Hector Sants says bankers should not be motivated solely by rewards and calls for integrity within banking system
fields.body:
Hector Sants, chief executive of the Financial Services Authority, has criticised top bankers for continuing to take their bonuses and said they should act with "integrity" when running their businesses.

Speaking to the Guardian after delivering his last speech as chief executive of the City regulator, Sants also said he was concerned about the way directors of large financial institutions are selected.

The 56-year-old, who will leave the FSA in June after eight years, insisted that his decision to step down, rather than become deputy governor of the Bank of England and head of the new Prudential Regulation Authority, was solely because he wanted to do a different job.

After addressing an invited audience in the City, Sants told the Guardian: "If I had been a senior bank executive in the last three or four years I would have taken a different view about individual pay levels than many, but not all, of the banks did. I think that would have been a very good signal, which would be part of the restoration of trust."

Sants did not take his own £130,000 bonus for the 2008-09 financial year and, since then, has handed his £100,000-a-year bonus to charity.

He said City bosses should be motivated not only by the potential rewards: "Should there not be some level of expectation that people entrusted with the leadership of financial services organisations ultimately are driven by the desire to 'do the right thing'? It's called integrity and it is what we all, as users of financial services, expect of the leaders of the sector."

Sants said that in the runup to the financial crisis, "integrity seems to have been in short supply, in the sense that when making their major decisions there seems to have been an absence of focus on whether this decision is going to deliver a good outcome for wider society as a whole and the long-term interest in general".

Reflecting on the failures of banks such as Royal Bank of Scotland and HBOS, he said that "there were … people in key positions in a number of those major financial institutions who didn't have the required technical competency" – an opinion he has shared with the Treasury select committee.

The FSA has since started to interview people regarded as holding "significant influence functions" – executives and non-executives who chair important committees such as risk and audit. Out of 653 applications in the past two years, 48 had been withdrawn, 39 because of concerns identified by the FSA. "There is a view held by some, unfortunately, that they are entitled to a position regardless of their skills and experience," Sants said. Bank chairmen, he has concluded, should always have financial services experience.

On pay, Sants called for more non-financial factors to be considered – such as the way customers are served, in light of the payment protection scandal – in addition to the usual measures of shareholder returns. Sants said: "I think that's what shareholders should want … We need to break this deadlock that we have between lack of trust in institutions, lack of long-term behaviour by executives and lack of engagement by the shareholders."

The FSA has been criticised for its handling of the banking crisis – as has Sants himself – but he insists that the FSA was constrained by its remit and could not intervene in takeovers such as the lethal RBS bid for ABN Amro. "All those firms failed because of decisions by their management. It's really important we don't let the management off the hook. There is a danger that people forget that it is up to the regulator to set boundaries in which the management make decisions."

He also denied any suggestion that the FSA could have taken action against former RBS boss Fred Goodwin but chose not to. The FSA has found the Bank of Scotland division of HBOS guilty of "serious misconduct", but is yet to offer opinions on its management team.

Sants said that he believed he was working in "partnership" with regulated firms when he first joined the FSA, but he now believed the relationship between financial firms and the watchdog should be one of "constructive tension".

webTitle: Too many duffers proposed for top jobs

fields.standfirst: Outgoing FSA chief Hector Sants says some candidates for senior posts at banks and insurers feel entitled to position 'regardless of skills and experience'
fields.body:
Hector Sants, in his last speech as chief executive of the Financial Services Authority, was interesting on the subject of the banks, insurers and financial firms proposing inappropriate and unqualified individuals to senior posts – or significant influence functions (SIFs), in the regulatory jargon.

I remain surprised at the gap between what some boards are doing and what the FSA believes they should be doing. And the FSA is still surprised by the number of times firms put forward candidates who are not the right individuals for the role in question and where there is no clear expectation of how that candidate will contribute to the overall skill and competence of the board. In these cases it is clear there has not been a robust appointments process undertaken by the firm.

The FSA, in its post-crisis intrusive guise, these days conducts interviews of SIF candidates – and has spotted plenty of duffers. Sants said that over the past two years the FSA has determined 653 applications – 48 were withdrawn, 39 of which "were demonstrably due to serious concerns identified by the FSA interview panel".

The list of failings is remarkable:

Too frequently we still see applicants who:
• don't understand what the job entails and have no job description;
• have done no due diligence into the firm they are proposing to join;

webTitle: Carpetright issues seventh profit warning as family budgets squeezed

fields.standfirst: Floor covering retailer says annual profits will be £3m-£4m, sharply down from October forecast of up to £17m
fields.body:
The struggling flooring specialist Carpetright has fired off its seventh profit warning in just over a year as rising living costs and a stagnant housing market stifles the high street.

Carpetright, which is run by its founder, Lord Harris, said annual profits would collapse to £3m-£4m, sharply down from the £12m to £17m forecast in October, after an ill-starred move into bed sales.

The specialist chain, which relies on people moving house to stimulate sales, made profits of £28m last year.

Carpetright's travails came as a key consumer spending barometer showed the spending power of the average UK household had fallen back to the levels of November 2008, when the country was mired in recession.

Families had £10 a week less to spend in March than a year ago, according to the Asda Income Tracker. The survey said households had disposable income of £144 in March, 6.5% lower than in 2011, as they struggled with higher utility bills and transport costs. The cost of electricity and gas remained well above last year, up more than 8% and 16% respectively in March, with petrol and diesel prices also more than 4% higher.

"Family budgets in 2012 are continuing to be squeezed by the three pressures of high unemployment, very weak wage increases and stubbornly elevated inflation," said Charles Davis, managing economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research. "While growth in the price of essentials is likely to fall back slowly this year, the tough conditions in the UK labour market look set to prevail."

The income tracker also showed some parts of the country continuing to be harder hit by the downturn than others, with households in Northern Ireland and the north-west of England much worse off than those in the south-east.

Irish families had £83 for extras compared with the UK average of £144, in the first quarter. In London, spending power was higher, at £184 a week for the three-month period.

Last week official figures showed the first rise in inflation for five months, partly due to higher food and clothing costs. The consumer price index rose to 3.5% in March, up from 3.4% in February, according to the Office for National Statistics, well above the average 1.1% pay rises being pushed through by companies.

The plight faced by Britons was also highlighted by latest figures from Kantar Worldpanel which showed the grocery market growing at 5% in the 12 weeks to 15 April, the biggest increase in more than two years due to higher food prices.

The squeeze is encouraging shoppers to go to "no frills" chains such as Lidl and Iceland, which posted sales uplifts that were streets ahead of that of the big four supermarkets.

Aldi chalked up growth of 27.9% in the 12 weeks to 15 April, compared with the market leader Tesco, which managed 4.2%.

Edward Garner, an analyst at Kantar, said shoppers were seeking out "strong value-for-money messages"; Waitrose was also beating the market as shoppers bought more expensive groceries rather than splash out on a restaurant meal.

"The discounters and Waitrose are outperforming the middle ground as shoppers polarise their spend," Garner said.

With many families struggling to cover the basics, household goods retailers like Carpetright, which has 475 stores in the UK, are finding it hard to drum up custom as big purchases such as a new carpet or bed are postponed. Although UK like-for-like sales did pick up to 1.4% in the 11 weeks to 14 April, its profits were hit after bed sales fell short of expectations.

"The fragile confidence of our customers continues to produce a weak and volatile floor coverings market," said Harris, its chairman and chief executive. He also blamed weak consumer confidence for a 4.4% drop in like-for-like sales at Carpetright's stores in the Netherlands, Belgium and Ireland.

"The group's ability to disappoint shows no sign of abating," said Keith Bowman, an equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers, who said Carpetright's management could "exempt" themselves from the deteriorating conditions in Europe but not the decision to move to selling beds. "Despite underlying progress, investor confidence has again been dented. For now, given the group's perceived correlation with consumer confidence, consensus opinion continues to denote a sell [on the shares]."

webTitle: Barclays' pay committee chair must go

fields.bodyText: The best thing Alison Carnwath could do at Barclays' annual meeting on Friday would be to resign as chair of the bank's remuneration committee. Carnwath has held the post for less than a year, so it seems unlikely she would be keen to quit even if the vote against her re-election as a director approaches the rumoured 15%. But Barclays, after the chaotic and bitter build-up to this year's annual meeting, needs to make a fresh start on pay – and that would be best achieved if Carnwath stood down from the pay committee. Barclays, remember, is an organisation that says it fully understands that pay arrangements in banking must change. "Compensation has to adjust to the new reality of lower returns for the sector," says chairman Marcus Agius. Part of the debate, then, is whether Barclays is adjusting fast enough in directing a greater share of the spoils towards shareholders and away from employees – and it's a large part of the job of Carnwath's committee to ensure that it does. Last week's concessions (chief executive Bob Diamond and finance director Chris Lucas volunteered to make half their 2011 bonuses subject to the eventual achievement of an acceptable return on capital) were, in effect, an admission that Barclays got it wrong. If the remuneration committee had done its job properly, a panicky 11th-hour attempt to contain the level of shareholder revolt would not have been necessary. If Carnwath had been on the ball and had lived up to her reputation as a tough boardroom cookie, she could have insisted on such conditionality in the first place. Instead her committee agreed simply staggering payouts to Diamond & co in a lousy year for the bank. The chief executive was awarded an annual bonus worth 200% of salary in a year in which return on equity fell from 7.2% to 5.8%. The financial performance was so far away from the ambition of 13% that Diamond himself labelled it "unacceptable". That judgment was reinforced by a graph that leaps from the pages of the remuneration report: £100 invested in the FTSE 100 index in December 2006 was worth £108 at the end of last year; £100 invested in Barclays shares became £29. Yet the pay committee seemed incapable of grasping the basic point that handing a total of £17m to Diamond (that's ignoring the £5.7m "tax equalisation" handout) in this circumstance would be also be unacceptable to a large constituency of shareholders. The only alternative explanation is that Carnwath lacked the bottle to deliver some hard truths to the executives. Either way, appointing a new chair of the remuneration committee would be quickest way to try to repair the damage to the bank's relations with its owners. Barclays is not alone in the banking world in dragging its feet on pay reforms. Citigroup's Vikram Pandit discovered that most shareholders disapproved of his pay last year; other US banks may also receive similar messages. But the fact that the banking industry as a whole finally seems to be exhausting the patience of shareholders is not a reason for Carnwath to cling on.

webTitle: All eyes on Fed as US investors look to gauge strength of spring recovery

fields.standfirst: Stock markets keenly await Ben Bernanke's update on the strength of the US economy following two-day policy meeting
fields.body:
The Federal Reserve is beginning its latest two-day policy meeting as investors nervously await an update on the US economy from chairman Ben Bernanke.

Economists and investors expect that the Fed will leave interest rates unchanged. But after mixed signals on the health of the US economy, they said Bernanke's statement and press conference – scheduled for the end of the meeting on Wednesday – could have a big influence on stock markets.

Bernanke and his colleagues ended their January meeting hinting they were considering a third round of bond-buying to pump more cash into the economy – a policy known as quantitative easing.

Since that meeting, reports have suggested that the US economy has strengthened. But there was disappointing news on the jobs front in March with the US adding just half the number of new positions it created in February.

The US housing market remains in the mire following the property crash. According to the latest S&P/Case-Shiller index, property values continued to fall in February, and average prices across 20 major cities are now at levels last seen in 2002.

The commerce department said on Tuesday that sales of new homes dropped in March to their lowest level in four months, but the figure beat analysts' expectations and the government said sales in prior months were higher than initially thought.

"We've had some positive news and some negative, especially on the jobs front. I'd like to know what they think," said Jack Ablin, chief investment officer with Harris Private Bank. For the past two years stock market rallies have fizzled out in the spring and investors continue to worry about a repeat of that patter, he said. "We are at an important juncture. If this is a very somber statement it will send a negative message to the market," said Ablin.

US thinktank the Conference Board released its latest consumer confidence index Tuesday. The index fell marginally to 69.2 in April compared to a revised 69.5 in the previous month.

Ken Goldstein, a Conference Board economist, said the marginal fall suggested people had not been overly affected by March's disappointing jobs numbers. He said that he expected Bernanke to deliver a "cautiously optimistic" statement about the economy.

"Despite the disappointing jobs numbers, the confidence index did not drop off. That suggests that this burgeoning sense of confidence is taking root," Goldstein said.

Capital Economics analyst Paul Ashworth said it was unlikely that Bernanke would make any big moves.

"The Fed's best option is to stay on the sidelines waiting to see which way the recovery breaks," he said.

webTitle: FTSE 100 regains some ground despite mixed US data, with Man leading the way on bid talk

fields.standfirst: Hedge fund group adds nearly 5% as UBS says it could be a bid target for north American asset manager
fields.body:
Leading shares recovered some of their losses after Monday's sell off, despite lingering eurozone worries and a mixed bag of US economic data, which prompted talk of further Federal Reserve measures to boost the world's largest economy.

Man was the biggest riser in the FTSE 100, as bid hopes returned after the hedge fund group's recent poor performance. It has been under pressure on worries about slowing growth and weak results from its key AHL fund. But its shares added 4.45p to 97p after UBS analysts said it could be a prime target for a north American asset manager, with a bid of 150p a share possibly being enough to win the day. Analyst Arnaud Giblat said a break up value on the business would be 100p, with any bidder having to pay a premium:

We estimate that Man is currently trading 5% below the combined value of AHL being run off (38p a share), GLG (33p a share), the institutional business (9p a share) and its net cash position (20p a share). With Man shares having traded below 150p for a six-month period, we believe that a 50% plus premium bid offer to the current share price would be sufficient to obtain shareholder approval.
We would not be surprised to see a bid from a north American asset manager that is trading on high earnings multiples, has surplus capital and has stated its intent to diversify geographies and product exposures.

Meanwhile Singer Capital Markets also repeated its buy rating on the business, albeit cutting its price target from 190p to 170p.

National Grid was also in demand. Its shares ended up 14.5p at 667.5p after Morgan Stanley moved its recommendation from equal weight to overweight ahead of regulator Ofgem publishing its initial review of the company's business plans in June. The bank said it believed the review would be much better for the company than originally feared, and that it was unlikely to need another cash call as had been suggested:

Concerns on new UK regulation are overdone, in our view; Grid will deliver decent growth and not require any equity issuance. The UK regulatory asset base will grow at 10% per annum, we estimate, justifying a higher valuation than other regulated utilities, and [its US business] should deliver improved returns and rate base growth. We think Grid could cut costs further. The culmination of the UK regulatory reviews and recent board changes could be the necessary catalysts.

Meanwhile UBS added the company to its top 40 global stock list due to its dividend yield, which it forecast would reach 6.2% this year.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 43.92 points higher at 5709.49 after its 106 point decline on Monday. There was still uncertainty over the situation in Holland, as its government resigned amid disagreements over its austerity budget. In the US consumer confidence was flat in April, disappointing analysts. New home sales fell by more than 7% in March while the S&P/Case Shiller house price index edged up 0.2% in February. But the Richmond Federal Reserve manufacturing index for April was higher than forecasts. The mixed signs prompted some suggestions the US Federal Reserve - which will hold a press conference on Wednesday following its latest two day meeting - could consider further quantitative easing.

Reed Elsevier rose 10.5p to 526p and Primark-owner Associated British Foods added 24p to £12.39 after investors warmed to their results.

But Capita lost 46.5p to 682.5p after the outsourcing group placed 40m shares at 685p each to raise around £274m. At the same time chief executive Paul Pindar made more than £2.7m by cashing in 400,000 of his shares, leaving him with 1.3m.

As it reported a 17% rise in first quarter sales, the company said it would use the funds for acquisitions. It spent £341m on bolt on businesses last year and £91m so far this year. After earlier being more cautious, it now believes it can spend another £90m or so in the rest of 2012:

The board had expected acquisition activity to reduce during 2012. However, in assessing the pipeline of potential opportunities since the preliminary results, the board has concluded the current acquisition environment continues to offer a rare opportunity to broaden the business.

But in a sell note analyst David Brockton at Espirito Santo said:

Today's newsflow reinforces our negative stance on Capita, with the group's reliance on acquisitions increasing and organic growth seemingly becoming more working capital consumptive, against a backdrop of a stretched balance sheet. While the risk to current year forecasts is low and Capita will likely return to some organic growth (around 2%-3%), the group has expanded its balance sheet to fund growth; this looks set to continue, and we believe it requires a lower rating than the group has otherwise historically derived.

Shares in chip designer Arm - whose customers include Apple and Microsoft - lost 35p to 531.5p on concerns as to whether its recent rapid growth could continue.

First quarter results showed revenues up 14% to £132.5m and profits up 22% to £61.9m. Licensing revenues grew by 20% but royalty revenues were hit by the disruption from October's floods in Thailand, climbing 8% overall.

But in the previous quarter overall revenues rose 21%, indicating a slowdown from the end of last year.

Imperial Tobacco lost 27p to £24.91 and British American Tobacco fell 56.5p to £31.57 after Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded its recommendation on the cigarette makers from outperform to neutral after the recent strong run in their shares.

Elsewhere housebuilder Redrow rose 9p to 126p after it said it would raise £80m to invest in the London market and elsewhere in the country. It is raising £19.4m with a firm placing of shares with Bridgemere Securities, controlled by chairman Steve Morgan. The rest of the cash will come from an open offer of three new shares for every 20 held. Morgan will underwrite the offer and could therefore end up with a much increased shareholding. He said:

There are an increasing number of land opportunities both in London and in the regions and as such we are looking to raise further capital to enable us to take advantage of these opportunities as they arise.

SuperGroup recovered 19.9p to 354.9p after its recent disappointing trading news but Carpetright closed 9p lower at 598p following its seventh profit warning in a year.

Finally Surgical Innovations, which makes instruments for keyhole surgery, fell 6% to 10.125p despite a 10% rise in profits to £1.7m. Analysts at WH Ireland kept their buy recommendation but cut their top of the range earnings forecast for the current year by 10%. They said:

We continue to believe that Surgical's niche positioning, increasing traction in the global marketplace and innovative product pipeline deserve a premium rating to the peer group. However, the reduction to our 2012 earnings per share forecast inevitably has implications for our target price which we also reduce by 10% from 15p to 13½p.

webTitle: UK set to avoid double-dip – just

fields.bodyText: Will it? Won't it? The financial markets are all agog about whether Wednesday's figures will show the UK economy mired in a double-dip recession. The betting in the City is that Britain will avoid that indignity, but if Tuesday's data for the public finances is anything to go by, it will be a close thing. The snapshot of the budget deficit in March provided a tasty appetiser for the GDP main course, with borrowing higher than a year ago for the second successive month. George Osborne could take some comfort from the fact that the headline borrowing total for 2011-12 was bang in line with his budget forecast of £126bn. That was down on the £136bn borrowed in 2010-11 but still means that since the economy plunged into recession in 2008 the government has run a cumulative budget deficit of £517bn. Deficits quickly mount up: in the last five years, the national debt has doubled to just over £1tn. These are big numbers, and explain why the coalition has put deficit reduction at the heart of its strategy. Spending – both on the running costs of government and on capital projects – is lower than projected a year ago, but so are revenues, which were just 1.4% higher in March than a year ago, and £16bn lower than forecast at the time of the 2011 budget. Receipts from income tax, VAT and corporation tax were all down year on year, despite the fact that inflation was running at more than double its 2% target for the bulk of the 2011-12 financial year. These figures will be a source of concern for Osborne. Tax receipts are a reasonably good – if not perfect – proxy for activity in the economy, since they illustrate trends in earning, spending and corporate profitability. The fact that all three were weak in February and March suggests that the economy was not exactly roaring away either. And, should the recent trend continue, the chancellor will struggle to bring the budget deficit in 2012-13 down to the £92bn pencilled in by the Office for Budget Responsibility.

webTitle: Wall Street opens higher after latest US house price survey

fields.standfirst: Index shows slight rise in US prices last month, as Federal Reserve starts latest two day meeting
fields.body:
Wall Street has opened higher in early trading following reasonable if slightly mixed US housing figures.

Prices of single family homes rose 0.2% in February, according to the S&P/Case Shiller index of 20 cities, the first increase since last April on a seasonally adjusted basis. But on a non-seasonally adjusted basis the index was down 0.8% to its lowest level since October 2002. Teunis Brosens at ING Bank said:

Previous months were revised down though, and as a result the 3.5% year on year fall is slightly worse than was expected.
That said, today's small month on month gain is definitely better than the continuous monthly price slippages we got used to in the second half of 2011. And as home sales continue to recover, prices should find increasing support. It is true that the recovery of existing home sales is progressing very slowly: sales in the first quarter were only 5% higher than a year ago. But this headline figure hides important shifts in the composition of sales. "Healthy" sales (not counting foreclosures and short sales) have improved 17% compared to a year ago. This should help prices in many cities finding a bottom in the coming months.

So the Dow Jones Industrial Average has added around 60 points initially. The FTSE 100 has slipped back from earlier highs as eurozone worries refuse to die down, and is now up just 7.13 points at 5672.70. France's Cac is up around 1%, Germany's Dax just 0.28% better.

The US Federal Reserve begins its latest two day get together on Tuesday, with a press conference at the end of the meeting, when chairman Ben Bernanke will give his latest views on the US economy, interest rates and quantitative easing.

webTitle: Action needed to tackle City excesses, Bank of England official warns

fields.standfirst: Andrew Haldane noted that performance measures in banking, such as returns on equity and executive compensation, rose dramatically in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis
fields.body:
A top Bank of England official has called for policy intervention to crack down on "financial arms races" in the City.

Speaking at the Institute for New Economic Thinking in Berlin, Andrew Haldane, executive director for financial stability and a member of the Financial Policy Committee (FPC), argued that structural features of the financial system can make it prone to arms-race-type behaviour.

Although financial arms races are not a new phenomenon, they have intensified with the growth of the financial industry over the past 30 years. Haldane used three examples to demonstrate this point.

First, he noted that performance measures in banking, such as returns on equity and executive compensation, rose dramatically in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis. As banks tried to keep up with their competitors by growing their balance sheets, returns on equity and executive pay spiralled. Generally, the bigger a firm's market value, the bigger the bonus.

"That Himalayan rise in bank executive salaries made the financial sector salary boom of even the 1920s look like a foothill," said Haldane. This resulted in a "high-leverage equilibrium" that "sowed the seeds of the financial crisis".

Secondly, the technological revolution in financial markets created a quest for speed in trading activities, dubbed a "race to zero". Haldane argued that the emergence of high-frequency trading, which has some clear benefits, also created uncertainties. Thirdly, investors' pre-crisis quest for return has been replaced by a quest for safety. As a result, a large and rising number of global banks' refinancing has taken place on secured terms. But Haldane argued that the quest for individual safety may generate system-wide instability: "At high levels of encumbrance, the financial system as a whole may even be riskier, as it is more susceptible to pro-cyclical swings in the underlying value of banks' assets."

Haldane suggests that these arms races – in return, speed, and safety – could have been prevented. But to be effective, policy intervention would have needed to constrain behaviour across the financial system as a whole. In other words, "policy needs to have a macro-prudential, as distinct from micro-prudential, perspective".

Haldane then turned to the tools that agencies such as the FPC might need to tackle financial arms races. Constraints on banks' leverage could have "defused the return on equity race at source". Restrictions on cash distributions by banks, a favoured recommendation of the FPC over the past six months, can also help. Haldane welcomed measures such as maximum order cancellation ratios and strengthening circuit-breakers to curb speed races in financial markets. Finally, the FPC has paid increasing attention to the systemic risk posed by rising levels of bank encumbrance (the fraction of banks' liabilities that are secured against their assets). Haldane suggests that greater transparency and maximum limits on asset encumbrance could be considered.

webTitle: UK government meets borrowing target for financial year

fields.bodyText: The British government borrowed more than expected last month, but still managed to meet its target for the financial year. City economists said the high March shortfall highlighted the pressure on the chancellor to stick to his austerity measures, especially as the credit rating agencies Moody's and Fitch have put the UK's AAA-rating on negative outlook. But Labour warned that George Osborne risked choking off the recovery, with falling tax receipts last month underlining the fragile state of the economy. Public sector net borrowing, excluding the effect of the banking bailouts – the government's preferred measure – rose to £18.2bn last month, from £18bn a year ago, according to the Office for National Statistics. This was worse than the £16bn predicted by City economists. Tax receipts fell and government departments went on an unusually large spending splurge ahead of the end of the fiscal year. However, downward revisions to previous months (the February shortfall was trimmed to £12.2bn from the previously reported £15.2bn) meant Osborne met his full-year target. The government borrowed £126bn over the 2011/12 financial year, bang in line with the Office for Budget Responsibility's forecast in the March budget, and far below the £136.8bn deficit run up last year. "These figures show that last year George Osborne borrowed £9bn more than he planned to at the time of his spending review," said Rachel Reeves, Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury. "There do need to be tough decisions on tax, spending and pay. But by choking off the recovery, pushing up unemployment and so borrowing billions more to pay for economic failure, cutting spending and raising taxes too far and too fast has backfired. And this government's pledge to balance the books by 2015 is now in tatters." As a percentage of GDP, borrowing fell to 8.3% in 2011/12 from 9.3% in 2010/11, also in line with government forecasts. The chancellor has vowed to largely eliminate Britain's budget deficit in coming years. It was at a record 11% when the coalition government took power in 2010. Britain's net debt climbed to £1.02tn in March, equivalent to 66% of GDP, the highest since records began in 1993. When the government set out its deficit reduction plans in 2010, it pencilled in tax increases worth £29bn and spending cuts worth £83bn over the next five years. However, Blerina Uci at Barclays Capital said the five-year plan had turned into a seven-year plan: "The OBR has lowered its GDP growth forecast for 2011-12 to 0.5% from 2.4% and its 2012-13 forecast to 1% from 2.9%. This has led the government to slow the pace of fiscal consolidation in the medium term. The government has eased both the pace of spending cuts and the pace of tax increases – the net effect has, however, been for fiscal consolidation to last for longer and to be even more severe in the long run (cumulative spending cuts have increased to £126bn)." Tax receipts were disappointing in March, which suggests that weaker economic activity took its toll. Income and capital gains tax receipts were down by 3.6% year-on-year, while the VAT take fell 1%. "With the economic recovery continuing to stutter, we think it will become increasingly difficult for the government to meet its ambitious deficit reduction plans in the coming fiscal year," said Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics.

webTitle: UK government borrowing: what the experts say

fields.standfirst: Government borrowing was higher than expected last month, but downward revisions to previous months meant that over the 2011/2012 year the deficit was bang in line with £126bn target
fields.body:
Government borrowing was higher than expected last month, but downward revisions to previous months meant that over the 2011/2012 year the deficit was bang in line with the £126bn target. Find out what City economists and Labour made of the numbers.

Nida Ali, economic advisor to the Ernst & Young ITEM Club

A lacklustre end to the financial year, with March seeing a slight increase in public borrowing, compared to a year earlier. However, thanks to strong figures in the first 10 months of the financial year, this didn't prevent the chancellor from meeting the OBR's forecast of lowering borrowing to £126bn in 2011/12.

It is discouraging that the rate of increase in central government spending outpaced the rise in tax revenues. A closer look at the release reveals some unpalatable trends. For instance, VAT receipts that until the end of last year, had been boosted by the increased VAT rate, fell in March reflecting weak consumer spending.

The outlook for the UK's public finances is very uncertain. The eurozone crisis continues to pose a significant threat to the economic outlook, and it's possible that the OBR's growth forecasts will prove to be too optimistic. This will inevitably have adverse consequences for public finances and suggests that borrowing may not come down as quickly as the OBR currently expects.

Allan Monks, UK economist at JPMorgan Chase

Although revenues undershot expectations for most of the year, spending was generally also lower than expected. But the last two monthly readings have shown both weaker tax revenues and higher spending. The OBR's forecast for lower borrowing in the upcoming fiscal year, which started in April, implies this recent trend will reverse.

Blerina Uci, UK economist, Barclays Capital

We are now 22 months into the five-year fiscal consolidation plan the government announced in June 2010, when it laid out plans to eliminate the structural deficit by the end of the current parliament. To this end it announced tax increases worth £29bn and spending cuts worth £83bn cumulatively over the five-year period. Since then, activity data has been significantly worse than expected – the OBR has lowered its GDP growth forecast for 2011-12 to 0.5% from 2.4% and its 2012-13 forecast to 1.0% from 2.9%. This has led the government to slow the pace of fiscal consolidation in the medium term and the five-year plan has turned into a seven-year plan.

The government has eased both the pace of spending cuts and the pace of tax increases – the net effect has, however, been for fiscal consolidation to last for longer and to be even more severe in the long run (cumulative spending cuts have increased to £126bn).

At the time of this year's budget, the OBR forecast that the government would borrow £77bn more during the course of this parliament than the interim OBR had expected at the time of the June 2010 "emergency" budget. As mentioned above, since June 2010 the OBR has lowered its forecast for GDP growth in 2012 and 2013 significantly. These set of revisions – higher borrowing, lower growth – ostensibly support the claim that government austerity has hit growth and in doing so made the deficit more difficult to eradicate.

It is worth noting, however, that this claim is at odds with the OBR's own analysis. Despite the downward revisions to GDP growth, the OBR now believes the cyclical component of the deficit will be £17bn lower over the course of this parliament than it had previously estimated. Although this seems counter-intuitive, it reflects the fact that revenues have generally not been as weak as the poor performance of the economy would have implied, leading the OBR to be a little more optimistic about future receipts.

The upward revision to borrowing is, in fact, more than accounted for by the change in the OBR's assessment of the structural deficit (specifically, the cyclically adjusted current budget), which it now estimates will be £115bn higher over the course of this parliament than it had thought in June 2010. This reflects the OBR's change of view about the past: in its November 2011 update it said it believed the financial crisis and recession had done more and more-lasting damage to the economy's productive potential than had previously been thought. Thus, in the OBR's view, the higher borrowing requirement over the course of this parliament is more a legacy of the imbalances that had built up in the economy prior to the financial crisis than the result of cyclical weakness in demand.

Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics

March's public finance figures suggest that the trend in the UK's fiscal position is continuing to worsen. Borrowing on the main measure came in at £18.2bn, thereby overshooting last year's figure of £18bn as well as the consensus forecast of £16bn. This is the second month in a row that borrowing has exceeded last year's total. At least favourable revisions to the borrowing figures in previous months has meant that borrowing for the 2011/12 fiscal year as a whole has come in at £126bn, in line with the OBR's budget forecast.

Weaker than expected growth in tax receipts, reflecting the slow pace of economic recovery, has been offset by lower than anticipated growth in current expenditure for the year as a whole. But with the economic recovery continuing to stutter, we think it will become increasingly difficult for the government to meet its ambitious deficit reduction plans in the coming fiscal year.

Howard Archer, chief UK and European economist at IHS Global Insight

The March public finance figures provided mixed news for chancellor George Osborne. While the chancellor will be pleased to have avoided an overshoot in the 2011/12 public sector net borrowing requirement, the increased deficit in March highlights the still parlous state of the public finances and highlights the pressure on Mr Osborne to maintain his tight fiscal stance – particularly as two credit agencies (Moody's and Fitch) have the UK's AAA credit rating on negative outlook.

Major uncertainty surrounds the release of the first-quarter GDP data on Wednesday due to the potential hit to the figures from reported very weak construction activity, but the chancellor will be desperately hoping that the economy shows at least underlying growth and that it can build from there. He needs growth in the economy not only to meet his fiscal targets for 2012/13 but also to stop pressure mounting for any easing of the fiscal squeeze to stimulate activity.

In March's budget, the chancellor set the target of reducing the PSNBR modestly further to £120bn in fiscal year 2012/13, with the reduction limited by anticipated GDP expansion of just 0.8% in 2012 before it improves to 2% in 2013. This looks achievable (although we forecast GDP growth to be modestly lower at 1.6% in 2013).

However, the chancellor could very well struggle to meet his longer term fiscal targets as he is relying on GDP growth picking up to 2.7% in 2014 and 3% in both 2015 and 2016, which currently looks pretty optimistic.

Rachel Reeves, Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury

These figures show that last year George Osborne borrowed £9bn more than he planned to at the time of his spending review. The government is now forecast to borrow an extra £150bn because of the higher unemployment and slow growth their failed economic policies have delivered.

There needs to be tough decisions on tax, spending and pay. But by choking off the recovery, pushing up unemployment and so borrowing billions more to pay for economic failure, cutting spending and raising taxes too far and too fast has backfired. And this government's pledge to balance the books by 2015 is now in tatters.

Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics March's public finance figures suggest that the trend in the UK's fiscal position is continuing to worsen. Borrowing on the main measure came in at £18.2bn, thereby overshooting last year's figure of £18bn as well as the consensus forecast of £16bn. This is the second month in a row that borrowing has exceeded last year's total. At least favourable revisions to the borrowing figures in previous months has meant that borrowing for the 2011/12 fiscal year as a whole has come in at £126bn, in line with the OBR's budget forecast. Weaker than expected growth in tax receipts, reflecting the slow pace of economic recovery, has been offset by lower than anticipated growth in current expenditure for the year as a whole. But with the economic recovery continuing to stutter, we think it will become increasingly difficult for the government to meet its ambitious deficit reduction plans in the coming fiscal year. While the chancellor will be pleased to have avoided an overshoot in the 2011/12 public sector net borrowing requirement, the increased deficit in March highlights the still parlous state of the public finances and highlights the pressure on Mr Osborne to maintain his tight fiscal stance – particularly as two credit agencies (Moody's and Fitch) have the UK's AAA credit rating on negative outlook. Major uncertainty surrounds the release of the first-quarter GDP data on Wednesday due to the potential hit to the figures from reported very weak construction activity, but the chancellor will be desperately hoping that the economy shows at least underlying growth and that it can build from there. He needs growth in the economy not only to meet his fiscal targets for 2012/13 but also to stop pressure mounting for any easing of the fiscal squeeze to stimulate activity. In March's budget, the chancellor set the target of reducing the PSNBR modestly further to £120bn in fiscal year 2012/13, with the reduction limited by anticipated GDP expansion of just 0.8% in 2012 before it improves to 2% in 2013. This looks achievable (although we forecast GDP growth to be modestly lower at 1.6% in 2013). However, the chancellor could very well struggle to meet his longer term fiscal targets as he is relying on GDP growth picking up to 2.7% in 2014 and 3% in both 2015 and 2016, which currently looks pretty optimistic. Rachel Reeves, Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury These figures show that last year George Osborne borrowed £9bn more than he planned to at the time of his spending review. The government is now forecast to borrow an extra £150bn because of the higher unemployment and slow growth their failed economic policies have delivered. There needs to be tough decisions on tax, spending and pay. But by choking off the recovery, pushing up unemployment and so borrowing billions more to pay for economic failure, cutting spending and raising taxes too far and too fast has backfired. And this government's pledge to balance the books by 2015 is now in tatters.

webTitle: Hedge fund group Man tops FTSE 100 risers on renewed bid talk

fields.standfirst: UBS analysts suggest company could be a prime target for north American asset manager
fields.body:
Man is heading the FTSE 100 risers as bid hopes return after its recent poor performance.

The hedge fund group has been under pressure on worries about slowing growth and weak results from its key AHL fund. But its shares have jumped 4.65p to 97.2p, a 5% increase, after UBS analysts said it could be a prime target for a north American asset manager. Analyst Arnaud Giblat said:

We estimate that Man is currently trading 5% below the combined value of AHL being run off (38p a share), GLG (33p a share), the institutional business (9p a share) and its net cash position (20p a share). With Man shares having traded below150p for a six-month period, we believe that a 50% plus premium bid offer to the current share price would be sufficient to obtain shareholder approval.
The acquirer would be paying ....for high-quality global distribution in onshore retail products, with a focus on the $1trn Asia-Pacific and Japanese markets. Growing such exposure organically has proven extremely difficult and costly for many asset managers. We would not be surprised to see a bid from a north American asset manager that is trading on high earnings multiples, has surplus capital and has stated its intent to diversify geographies and product exposures.

Meanwhile Singer Capital Markets also repeated its buy rating, albeit cutting its price target from 190p to 170p.

webTitle: Arm shares fall 3% on caution over growth prospects

fields.standfirst: Chip designer reports 14% first quarter revenue growth, down from final quarter of 2011
fields.body:
Shares in chip designer Arm - whose customers include Apple and Microsoft - have lost more than 3% on concerns as to whether its recent rapid growth could continue.

First quarter results showed revenues up 14% to £132.5m and profits up 22% to £61.9m. Licensing revenues grew by 20% but royalty revenues were hit by the disruption from October's floods in Thailand, climbing 8% overall.

But in the previous quarter overall revenues rose 21%, indicating a slowdown from the end of last year. The company said:

While first quarter industry shipments declined sequentially, most analysts expect the industryk to recover in the second half. In that context Arm expects that group dollar revenues for the full year 2012 will be in line with current market expectations.

On the plus side, Microsoft will be launching its first Windows operating system based on an Arm system, but it also faces growing competition from Intel in the smartphone and tablet markets which it has dominated. The company's shares have slipped 19.5p at 547p, making it the second biggest faller in the FTSE 100. Janardan Menon at Liberum Capital issued a sell note with a 500p price target, saying:

The company's outlook statement suggests some weakness in the second quarter of 2012 due to lower industry shipments in the first three months, but for a recovery in the second half to meet full year expectations. We do not expect forecasts to change materially after these results. The stock is trading at 46 times our forecasted 2012 earnings per share which we regard as being over-valued. We also expect Intel to gain momentum in the smartphone and tablet markets this year which is likely to depress sentiment.

Gareth Evans at Canaccord Genuity maintained a hold rating, saying the company seemed to be adopting a more cautious tone:

Guidance is very clear in terms of management expecting performance for 2012 "in line with" market consensus. Since January's comment that management expected performance "at least" in line with consensus, the consensus revenue has risen $20 million. We upgrade our forecasts to reflect management's comfort at this new higher level, although we note that its wording has become moderately more cautious in light of the new (upgraded) revenue expectation.
Arm's price will be driven, we believe, by news flow around Windows on Arm, success or otherwise of Intel's continued attempts to materially penetrate the smartphone segment, and any further clarity around the mobile marketplace in general. In the absence of significant further growth from mobile, we believe the non-mobile segments will have to contribute very strong performances to allow the group to achieve the strong long-term growth factored into expectations and the share price.

Investec's Julian Yates was more positive, however, maintaining his buy recommendation:

We see any weakness on the back of the royalty number (a one-off impact from Thai floods) as a good buying opportunity. The licence number was strong, supported by some backlog conversion. Aside of the one-off royalty impact, we see the results as expected, supporting the positive evolution of the model.

webTitle: FTSE edges higher as Shell agrees £1bn deal for Cove Energy, while Redrow and Capita raise cash

fields.standfirst: Oil giant raises offer for East African specialist Cove, as investors await decision from rival suitor PTT
fields.body:
There are renewed signs of companies going on a bit of a spending spree, with an oil industry bid and a couple of fundraisings for future acquisitions.

Cove Energy, the Mozambique-focused exploration group, has been the subject of a bidding war, but now it has recommended a new £1.12bn, 220p a share offer from Royal Dutch Shell. Shell has increased its original offer following a rival bid from Thailand's state controlled PTT. Cove's directors - who speak for more than 4% of the company - have accepted the bid, while PTT has said it is examining its options in the wake of the Shell move.

In the market Cove has climbed 8p to 225p as investors cling on to the hope of a rival offer, while Shell's A shares are 12p better at £21.22. Stuart Joyner at Investec said:

The Cove sale process has taken what may be its final turn with a recommended cash offer from Shell. The formal sale process has now concluded and the data room has closed. Competing offers can still be made and the shares will now likely trade to a slight premium on the hope that PTT (now the underbidder) will trump Shell. We raise our target to the bid level of 220p [from 195p] and remain at hold.

Meanwhile Capita has lost 29p to 690p after the outsourcing group unveiled plans to raise around £290m with a placing of around 40m shares. As it reported a 17% rise in first quarter sales, the company said it would use the funds for acquisitions. It spent £341m on bolt on businesses last year and £91m so far this year. After earlier being more cautious, it now believes it can spend another £90m or so in the rest of 2012:

The board had expected acquisition activity to reduce during 2012. However, in assessing the pipeline of potential opportunities since the preliminary results, the board has concluded the current acquisition environment continues to offer a rare opportunity to broaden the business.

In a sell note analyst David Brockton at Espirito Santo said:

Today's newsflow reinforces our negative stance on Capita, with the group's reliance on acquisitions increasing and organic growth seemingly becoming more working capital consumptive, against a backdrop of a stretched balance sheet. While the risk to current year forecasts is low and Capita will likely return to some organic growth (around 2%-3%), the group has expanded its balance sheet to fund growth; this looks set to continue, and we believe it requires a lower rating than the group has otherwise historically derived.

Elsewhere housebuilder Redrow said it would raise £80m to invest in the London market and elsewhere in the country. It is raising £19.4m with a firm placing of shares with Bridgemere Securities, controlled by chairman Steve Morgan. The rest of the cash will come from an open offer of three new shares for every 20 held. Morgan (who watched his Wolverhampton Wanderers football club relegated from the Premiership at the weekend) said:

There are an increasing number of land opportunities both in London and in the regions and as such we are looking to raise further capital to enable us to take advantage of these opportunities as they arise.

Overall the FTSE 100 has climbed 20.84 points to 5686.41, recovering a little from Monday's eurozone inspired slump. Worries about the collapse of the Dutch government were to the fore on Monday, but the country has just successfully conducted a bond auction, which has calmed some nerves.

Man is among the leading risers, up 3.3p to 95.85p after Singer Capital Markets issued a buy note, albeit cutting its price target from 190p to 170p.

Reed Elsevier rose 11p to 526.5p and Primark-owner Associated British Foods added 25p to £12.40 after their results.

But a big casualty is Carpetright, down 23.5p to 583.5p following its seventh profit warning.

webTitle: Irish mortgage arrears still rising, Bank of Ireland warns

fields.standfirst: Bank hopes impairment charges will fall this year from last year's high levels, but pace of reduction depends on its Irish residential mortgage book and commercial property markets
fields.body:
Bank of Ireland, the only Irish lender to escape nationalisation during the financial crisis, warned that arrears on residential mortgages are still rising, reflecting high unemployment.

The bank stills hopes that impairment charges will fall this year from last year's high levels, but the pace of reduction depends on its Irish residential mortgage book and commercial property markets.

The lender said: "Arrears in our Irish residential mortgage book have continued to increase reflecting the difficult economic environment in Ireland and elevated levels of unemployment. While consumer confidence surveys have shown improvements in the first three months of 2012, domestic economic indicators remain weak, unemployment remains elevated and residential property prices do not appear, as yet, to have fully stabilised." Ireland's unemployment rate was 14.3% in March.

A group of foreign investors bought a stake in the bailed-out bank last summer, saving it from being nationalised, while the state retained a 15% stake.

The lender also said that it had borrowed €4.8bn (£3.91bn) from the European Central Bank in its last long-term refinancing operation in February.

Bank of Ireland's loans to customers have dipped 3% to €99bn since the end of last year, while customer deposits are similar to the level recorded in December 2011, at €70bn. The bank, which is trying to strengthen its balance sheet and improve margins, said its loan-to-deposit ratio had improved slightly, to 142% from 144% at the end of 2011.

Having set itself a target to shed €10bn of non-core loan portfolios, Bank of Ireland has managed to offload €8.4bn of loans out of €8.6bn announced last year. It has agreed the sale of a further €900m of international corporate and residential mortgage loans, including €600m of mortgages to ITL, a subsidiary of Coventry Building Society.
